thread.title: Eugene O’Neill channels Norman Rockwell at ACT
thread.title_full: Eugene O’Neill channels Norman Rockwell at ACT - San Francisco Chronicle

author: Robert Hurwitt
title: Eugene O’Neill channels Norman Rockwell at ACT
text:
Photo: Kevin Berne Nat Miller (Anthony Fusco, left) and brother-in-law Sid Davis (Dan Hiatt) discuss a letter that Nat's son Richard received from his girlfriend in ACT's revival of Eugene O'Neill's "Ah, Wilderness" Nat Miller (Anthony Fusco, left) and brother-in-law Sid Davis (Dan...
“Ah, Wilderness!” may still be one of Eugene O’Neill’s most popular plays, but the 1933 comedy has long since been eclipsed by his later masterpieces “Long Day’s Journey Into Night,” “The Iceman Cometh” and “A Moon for the Misbegotten.” “Moon” gets staged much more often around here, perhaps because it requires a much smaller cast. The American Conservatory Theater “Wilderness” that opened Wednesday, Oct. 21, provides some other good reasons. Nat Miller (Anthony Fusco, left) and brother-in-law Sid Davis (Dan Hiatt) discuss a letter that Nat's son Richard received from his girlfriend in ACT's revival of Eugene O'Neill's "Ah, Wilderness" Nat Miller (Anthony Fusco, left) and brother-in-law Sid Davis (Dan...
“Ah, Wilderness!” may still be one of Eugene O’Neill’s most popular plays, but the 1933 comedy has long since been eclipsed by his later masterpieces “Long Day’s Journey Into Night,” “The Iceman Cometh” and “A Moon for the Misbegotten.” “Moon” gets staged much more often around here, perhaps because it requires a much smaller cast. The American Conservatory Theater “Wilderness” that opened Wednesday, Oct. 21, provides some other good reasons.
